history.content:
<md>if you're a junior then this is your last chance to really do research and if you seriously think you want to do a phd program then you should take it depends on the company but for most tech companies they probably aren't going to care esp if you tell them you're doing research vs reneging on them for another company which would be bm but the reality is good engineers are hard to find so a company who holds grudges in recruiting is going to have a tough time really i mean it there is no way that reneging on an intern offer is going to affect your area of research maybe in hardware hardware people are kind of old school but in software stuff no way and in ai or ml stuff talent is just too hard to find

now if you are a sophomore just chill out do the internship because it's probably your first real experience in industry and for most people the industry life is a good life and is the right thing for them because research is hard it's overworked and underappreciated and industry pays well and they give you hella perks so just do the internship maybe think about doing (3)

overall your best plan is probably (3) because it's least bm and doing research during the summer when you aren't doing anything else is a big deal because you can actually spend 40-60 hours a week but good luck doing more than 10 hours a week of research during the school year if you don't clear out your schedule and want to do any extracurriculars it's just hard homie 

good luck phd grind is hard</md>

children.subject: <md>shorter internships are usually a bad idea because you're under too much pressure to get your project done since it is usually scoped for a full 3 months also companies are often unwilling to do shorter internships because there is less time to evaluate you</md>

I don’t have any good advice regarding which option is better but just a thought- We have 3 months of summer, maybe you can try communicating with the company and see if you can do the internship for a shorter length of time and dedicate the rest to research?
The student answer's lack of punctuation is impressive.

history.content:
Last semester I recruited for summer internships and accepted an offer at a fairly large company that I was happy with. At the time, I was mostly set on doing SWE after college and this was the natural path for me to take. However, since then I've become more involved in research/classes, enjoyed them a lot, and am seriously considering applying to PhD programs (although still undecided).

Obviously, staying over the summer to focus completely on research could help me decide whether this is really what I want to do, and would definitely be the best choice if I do end up applying for grad school. But I'm conflicted because I would essentially have to cancel my already-accepted internship offer just a few months in advance. If I end up realizing that SWE is still want I want to do, I'd probably be blacklisted from this company. Even if I go to grad school, this company is heavily involved in my area of research and I don't know if this would affect my future opportunities there as well.

I know there's a lot of discussion/controversy around reneging on internship offers, but I feel like this is a strange case because I'm not trying to take a "better" internship offer, it has more to do with me not knowing if SWE is right for me and wanting to figure out my future goals while I still have time. Has anyone been in this situation or have advice? I guess my options right now that I can imagine are:

(1) Canceling summer internship to do research

(2) Doing the internship despite having plans for grad school, and simply focusing on research in the fall/spring 

(3) Doing summer research and moving the internship to the fall or some other time (to do work + research instead of taking classes)
history.subject: Canceling internship plans to do research
